title: Know thyself
summary: The Ancient Greek aphorism "know thyself" (Greek: γνῶθι σεαυτόν, transliterated: gnōthi seauton; also ... σαυτόν … sauton with the ε contracted) is one of the Delphic maxims and was the first of three maxims inscribed in the pronaos (forecourt) of the Temple of Apollo at Delphi according to the Greek writer Pausanias (10.24.1).[1] The two maxims that followed "know thyself" were "nothing to excess" and "surety brings ruin".[2] In Latin the phrase, "know thyself", is given as nosce te ipsum[3] or temet nosce.[4]
